summary:
Dee Brillenburg Wurth retired early from the United Nation where she was the Senior Child Protection Advisor to three Peacekeeping Missions in Burundi, Afghanistan and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). 
Her responsibilities included advising mission leadership, Government and Non-state actors on issues relating to children in armed conflict, monitoring and reporting on grave child rights violations, and building the capacity of local actors to stop and prevent child recruitment and sexual abuse. She has worked to mitigate the impact of armed conflicts on children for more 25 years. 

Among her achievements in the DRC is the release of more than 3,000 children through direct face to face negotiation with armed group leaders in North and South Kivu, between 2018 and 2020, meeting the warlords on their own territory.  These meetings led to irreversible change, as 29 of the 31 rebel leaders that Dee met reportedly did not recruit any girls or boys after the negotiations.

Before joining the United Nations Dee worked for a number of international NGOâ€™s in other war-affected countries, including Kosovo, Albania, Sri Lanka, Sierra Leone, Ivory Coast, Senegal, Guinea and East Timor. Her main areas of interest are prevention, rehabilitation and reintegration of child soldiers, child rights promotion through media (TV, radio and print) and advocacy. 

In 1999 Dee wrote a 10-part drama series for Young Asia television (YA TV) which included topics such as child soldiers, slavery, HIV/AIDS, sex tourism, the caste system, arranged marriages and child suicide. YA TV is an English speaking channel, reaching 200 million young viewers in Sri Lanka, Nepal, India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. 

Before embarking on a career in war zones, Dee was a soap writer in the Netherlands.
